awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Novel platform for the preparation of samples for cryo-TEM imaging: capturing biomacromolecules repeatably in vitreous ice without artifacts
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is a new way to prepare samples for life sciences research by addressing the major bottleneck in the associated workflow.  The proposed work advances a new method to prepare biological samples for analysis to develop crisp, high-resolution 3D models of molecules. This will result faster acquisition of higher quality data and better 3D models of proteins and other cellular components, providing new insight into human biology and improvements to human health. 

The proposed project aims to solve the largest issues currently experienced in cryogenic Transmission Electron Microscopy (cryo-EM) sample preparation. Current sample preparation technologies are unreliable and require preparation of excess grids to acquire enough quality data for a 3D model of a biomacromolecule.  Many grids are of poor quality and generate insufficient data for a high-resolution protein model; or samples may contain artifacts from interaction at the air/water interface, reducing the ultimate resolution.  This Phase II project will advance an innovative design concept to repeatably prepare high quality samples with a blotless sample preparation technique.  The proposed work will explore the trade space and optimize process parameters for image resolution, leading to an advanced prototype.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Cryogenic Electron Microscopy (cryoEM) has become a foremost tool for structural biology research. Advances in microscope, camera, and data processing technology have enabled the Single Particle Analysis (SPA) workflow of cryoEM to rival X-ray crystallography as the most used analytical technique in reconstructing the 3D structure of biomolecules. A protein sample is spread onto a Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) grid and then vitrified, i.e. frozen fast enough that water is frozen into amorphous ice rather than crystallized, which interferes with imaging with a TEM. The sample is then imaged with a TEM. Ideally, Brownian motion results in protein particles randomly oriented in the ice upon vitrification, and they are arrested in that position and the subsequent images will show 2D representations of the population of random particle orientations. Images of each orientation can then be grouped together and averaged so that signal to noise ratio can be improved. The multiple averaged 2D representations/orientations can then be combined to create a 3D reconstruction of the protein.

For the sample to vitrify on the TEM grid, the sample fluid layer on the grid must be on the order of 10?s to 100?s of nm thick. Traditionally, to achieve this, sample applied to the TEM grid was blotted away from the grid with filter paper and then plunged into liquid ethane to be vitrified. Automated commercial blotting systems were developed that enabled control of blotting parameters such that a relatively repeatable process could be ascertained that provided appropriate ice thickness and sample conditions for successful SPA results. However, although this works for some proteins, it was discovered that particles have a disposition towards adsorbing to the air/water interface of the thinned fluid sample layer, which often results in the particles taking on a preferred orientation, reducing the number of 2D particle representations present in images and ultimately the quality of the 3D reconstruction of the protein. The traditional blotting process occurs too slowly resulting in significant effects of this air/water interface interaction.

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project has resulted in a new blotless cryoEM sample preparation process that mitigates the effect of the air/water interface on particle orientation in vitrified SPA samples.   Increased randomness of particle orientation is achieved through a reduction in time between the formation of the fluid sample layer and vitrification. Continued development will further quantify this improvement with a variety of protein samples. Ultimately the process will be integrated into a commercial platform for cryoEM sample preparation.  This product could have major positive impacts on structural biology, virology and pharmaceutical development.

 


Last Modified: 02/06/2023
Modified by: Michael Godfrin
